awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Evolving the mammalian forelimb: modeling musculoskeletal transformation in the forerunners of mammals
awd_abstract_narration:
A unique feature of mammals is their many different forelimb shapes and functions, including highly distinct forelimbs for running, climbing, digging, swimming, and flying. No other group of animals has such diverse forelimbs, and the flexibility of mammal forelimbs seems to be a key reason for the group's success. The first mammal relatives found in the fossil record are over 300 million years old, and are a striking contrast to living mammals: their forelimbs show a very limited range of shapes and functions. How did the evolutionarily-flexible forelimbs of mammals evolve from such seemingly constrained ancestors, and did changes to the forelimb increase the ability of mammals to explore new ways of life? This research project will use state-of-the-art techniques, and extensive data from fossils and modern animals, to reconstruct forelimb structure and function in ancient mammal relatives, and to test whether changes to the forelimb correlate with increases in their ecological diversity. The results will deepen our understanding of the evolution of a quintessential characteristic of mammals, and its role in the evolution of animals as distinct as bats, moles, whales, horses, and humans. Dissemination of the research will occur through a series of educational online videos produced by the award-winning YouTube Channel "The Brain Scoop". The series will include three episodes describing different stages of the research, and two episodes that describe the results and their significance. Audience responses to the videos will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of online videos as a tool for science education.

Modern mammals display remarkable ecomorphological diversity, which is underpinned by exaptation of the forelimb to serve novel functions (e.g. flying, running, swimming, and digging). In contrast, the ancestors of mammals - the non-mammalian synapsids - are generalized terrestrial tetrapods with seemingly limited ecological scope. The mammalian-style forelimb, including a fully mobile scapula, ventrally oriented ball-and-socket shoulder joint, and "upright" limb posture and movement, is the result of a profound reorganization of the ancestral synapsid musculoskeletal system. Drawing from the extensive synapsid fossil record, this project integrates a diverse set of methodological techniques to pinpoint how morphofunctional transformation of the forelimb influenced the tempo and mode of phenotypic evolution of the synapsid clade. Rigorous morphometric analyses will quantify shape disparity in forelimb skeletal elements and identify major shifts in morphology. Cutting-edge biomechanical analyses will correlate morphological shifts with functional transformation. And, advanced phylogenetic modeling techniques will determine whether shifts in morphology and function resulted in increases in diversification rates. Key products include a new comprehensive metatree of Synapsida, an extensive geometric morphometric dataset, and 3D musculoskeletal models of ten taxa at phylogenetically informative stages of synapsid evolution. Combined, this project will build a robust comparative framework to quantify musculoskeletal transformations in extinct animals and provide a unique evolutionary perspective on an integrated anatomical module of significant adaptive value.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modern mammals display remarkable a remarkable diversity of forms and ways of life, many of which are underpinned by modifications of the forelimb to serve novel functions (e.g., flying, running, swimming, and digging). In contrast, the ancestors of mammals - the non-mammalian synapsids - are generalized terrestrial animals with more limited ways of life. The mammalian-style forelimb, including a highly mobile shoulder joint and ‘upright’ limb posture and movement, is the result of a profound reorganization of the ancestral synapsid anatomy over the course of ~300 million years. With funding from this grant, we sought to develop a comprehensive family tree of non-mammalian synapsids to serve as a framework for analyses of evolutionary patterns, and to document the evolutionary history of the synapsid forelimb in much greater detail than in previous investigations.

The comprehensive family tree we built includes 1,888 species and synthesizes information from 269 previous studies. In an initial use of this tree, we tested the common assumption that the ancestors of major evolutionary radiations of synapsids were usually small meat-eaters (‘faunivores’). We found that the ancestors of the major synapsid diversifications were indeed faunivores, but small body size is only characteristic of the most recent radiations of mammals and their close relatives. The ancestors of older radiations were larger animals, and the change to smaller ancestral sizes is the result of only small synapsids surviving a mass extinction event about 200 million years ago.

Focusing on forelimb evolution, we found that high levels of forelimb shape variation have a deep history in mammals and their ancestors that stretches back over 260 million years. Furthermore, past synapsid lineages evolved a wide range of forelimb shapes, and explored areas of ‘shape space’ that are no longer occupied by living animals. Some forelimb shapes evolved multiple times, and shapes similar to those of modern mammals evolved relatively late in synapsid history, close to the origin of marsupial and placental mammals. Considering forelimb function, both modern reptiles and mammals show specializations of their forelimbs for increased efficiency and mobility relative to their early ancestors, although each group displays a unique suite of functional traits reflecting their different limb postures. Early synapsid limbs are optimized more for stability and strength in a ‘sprawling’ posture than those of most modern mammals and reptiles, although the forelimbs of modern egg-laying mammals (platypus and echidna) are somewhat similar. Other synapsids optimized their limbs for different combinations of functions, but only a few approached those of modern mammals until quite late in synapsid history. Moreover, very few fossil synapsids had forelimbs optimized for functions similar to those of modern reptiles. These results contradict past conventional wisdom that early synapsids had limbs that were functionally similar to those of modern reptiles, and that synapsid limb evolution consisted of a step-wise accumulation of mammal-like characteristics that extended over most of the group’s history.

We communicated our results to the general public through an episode of the popular YouTube series SciShow, which has been viewed over 261,000 times. Audience members were engaged by the content, on average watching about two-thirds of the video. Comments left by viewers show that members of the public readily used aspects of our research to reconsider familiar facets of their lives, and the tone of the comments suggests that they found that process enjoyable and thought-provoking. The project supported the professional development of one Ph.D. student who is now a tenure-track faculty member at the University of Oklahoma, two postdoctoral researchers, and one undergraduate student who is now a Ph.D. student at the University of Chicago.
